diagrams.description: Nuclear engineering emerged from the discovery of radioactivity (1896) by Henri Becquerel and subsequent research by Marie and Pierre Curie. 1905 brought Einstein's E=mc² equation establishing mass-energy equivalence. 1932 witnessed neutron discovery (James Chadwick) and 1938 saw nuclear fission discovery (Otto Hahn, Fritz Strassmann). The Manhattan Project (1942-1945) developed the first nuclear weapons and created the first controlled nuclear chain reaction (Enrico Fermi, Chicago Pile-1, 1942). The 1950s marked peaceful nuclear energy development with the first nuclear power plant (Obninsk, USSR, 1954) and first commercial US reactor (Shippingport, 1957). The 1960s-70s witnessed rapid nuclear power expansion worldwide and development of various reactor designs. The 1979 Three Mile Island accident and 1986 Chernobyl disaster prompted enhanced safety regulations. The 1990s-2000s brought Generation III+ reactor designs with improved safety features. 2011's Fukushima accident further advanced safety standards. The 2010s-2020s continue with small modular reactor development, Generation IV concepts, fusion energy progress (ITER project), and advanced fuel cycles emphasizing sustainability and waste reduction.

timeline
    title The History of Nuclear Engineering
    section Early Discoveries
        1895 : Wilhelm Röntgen discovers X-rays
        1896 : Henri Becquerel discovers radioactivity
        1938 : Otto Hahn and Fritz Strassmann discover nuclear fission
    section The Manhattan Project
        1942 : Chicago Pile-1, the first artificial nuclear reactor
        1945 : The Trinity test, the first detonation of a nuclear weapon
    section The Atomic Age
        1951 : Experimental Breeder Reactor I (EBR-I), the first to generate electricity
        1954 : The first nuclear submarine, USS Nautilus
        1957 : The first commercial nuclear power plant (Shippingport, Pennsylvania)
    section The Cold War and Beyond
        1979 : Three Mile Island accident
        1986 : Chernobyl disaster
    section The 21st Century
        2000s : Development of Generation III+ reactors
        2010s : Renewed interest in small modular reactors (SMRs)
